Fig. 1 The relation of plating temperature and plating time. Fig. 2 The catalytic activity of NiP(B)/Al2O3 materials that were made at different plating temperature. Fig. 3 The relationship of initial pH values of plating and the catalytic activities. Fig. 4 The relationship of the NiP loading amounts of NiP(B)/Al2O3 and the catalytic activities. Fig. 5 Effects of the drying temperatures on the catalytic activities of NiP(B)/Al2O3. Fig. 6 Catalytic activities of NiP(B)/Al2O3 and NiB/Al2O3. Fig. 7 XRD characterization of catalyst. Fig. 8 XRD characterization of catalyst treated at 420°C. Fig. 9 SEM morphologies of catalysts, photos a–c show the different morphologies of NiP(B)/Al2O3 catalysts; photo d and photo g show the surface morphology of the amorphous NiP(B)/Al2O3 which had carried out in the reaction for about 24h; photo e shows the surface morphology of fresh NiB/Al2O3; photo f shows the morphology of the deactivated NiB/Al2O3; photo k shows the morphology of the fresh NiPB. Fig. 10 XPS spectra of NiP(B)/Al2O3, (I) P 2p; (II) B 1s; (III) Ni 2p3/2. Fig. 11 XPS spectra of pellet NiP(B)/Al2O3 catalysts, (I) Ni 2p3/2; (II) P 2p; (III) B 1s, catalyst a is the fresh pellet NiP(B)/Al2O3 catalyst; catalyst b represents the catalyst that resulted when catalyst a had been dried in air at 120°C about 10h; catalyst c represents the catalyst that resulted when catalyst b had been used in the reaction for about 36h. Fig. 12 XPS of pulverous NiP(B)/Al2O3. Fig. 13 Catalytic activities of powder and pellet NiP(B)/Al2O3 catalysts. Table 1 Some catalysts made at different plating temperatures used in the reaction Number Catalyst Plating temperature (°C) Drying temperature (°C)/time (h) 1# NiB/Al2O3 – 120/10 2# NiP(B)/Al2O3 80 120/10 3# NiP(B)/Al2O3 60 120/10 4# NiP(B)/Al2O3 40 120/10 5# NiP(B)/Al2O3 20 120/10 6# NiP(B)/Al2O3 70 90/10 7# NiP(B)/Al2O3 70 120/10 8# NiP(B)/Al2O3 70 150/10 9# NiP(B)/Al2O3 70 180/10 10# NiP(B)/Al2O3 70 250/10 11# NiP(B)/Al2O3 70 420/10 Table 2 Binding energies (eV) of standard substances [17] (all these substances are commercially available) Standard substances XPS level Binding energy (eV) Pure Ni Ni 2p3/2 852.7±0.2 NiO Ni 2p3/2 853.9±0.1 NiSiO3 Ni 2p3/2 856.8±0.1 Ni(OH)2 ·H2O Ni 2p3/2 855.5±0.1 Amorphous B B 1s 187.0±0.1 H3BO3 B 1s 193.0±0.1 B2O3 B 1s 193.3±0.1 B B 1s 187.3±0.1 Pure red P P 2p 129.0±0.1 BaHPO3 P 2p 133.8±0.1 Synthesis of hydrogen peroxide from carbon monoxide, water and oxygen catalyzed by amorphous NiP(B)/Al2O3 Zhong-Long Ma a b ⁎ Shao-Kun Jiang b Lun Zhang b Chuan-Qiang Liu b a Tianjin Lishen Battery Joint-Stock Co., Ltd., Tianjin 300384, China b State Key Laboratory of Chemical Engineering, School of Chemical Engineering and Technology, Tianjin University, Tianjin 300072, China ⁎ Corresponding author. Tel.: +86 22 27890798; fax: +86 22 27406204. Amorphous NiP(B)/Al2O3 catalysts were prepared by a coating method. The factors that influence the preparation of the catalysts, such as plating temperature, the initial pH value of the plating solution, the loadings of NiP and the temperature of heat treatment, were studied in detail. The catalysts were characterized with XRD, SEM and XPS, and were studied in the reaction for the synthesis of hydrogen peroxide from carbon monoxide, water and oxygen. The results showed that the catalysts had amorphous structure with Ni–P–B alloy formed on the surface; that the catalysts had better activity and stability than the catalysts reported previously when the H2O2 production rate reached 0.228mmol/(gh), which is higher than the maximum rate of 0.1mmol/(gh) over noble catalysts (5% Pd/CaCO3 and 1% Ru/graphite) and 0.07mmol/(gh) over Ni–La–B/Al2O3 catalyst; and that the preparation conditions significantly influenced the activities of the catalysts. The higher stability values of the catalysts were attributed to the amorphous Ni–P–B structure. Keywords Amorphous alloy NiP(B)/Al2O3 Carbon monoxide Oxygen Hydrogen peroxide 1 Introduction Hydrogen peroxide is a green oxidant, which has been widely used in the pulp and paper industry, and for environment protection. Currently, hydrogen peroxide is mainly produced by the anthraquinone process. However, this process has several drawbacks: many operation steps are needed and the production cost is high. In order to meet the increasing demands of hydrogen peroxide, alternative production methods are required. The direct synthesis of hydrogen peroxide from H2 and O2 has been reported [1–4], but this process is complex and costly because of the safety problems. The synthesis of H2O2 from CO, H2O and O2 is promising due to the safety and low reaction pressure of the process. The main reaction in this synthesis is thermodynamically favored: O 2 + CO + H 2 O → H 2 O 2 + C O 2 Δ G 298 ° = − 134 kJ mo l − 1 Yermakov et al. [5] first brought the reaction to completion by using palladium triphenylphosphane as catalyst in 1979. Bianchi [6] found that palladium complexes with bidentate nitrogenligands also showed high activity for this reaction. Brill [7] reported that Pd/CaCO3 and Ru/graphite catalysts could also be used for this reaction. However, in these works noble metals were used as the active components in the catalysts, which may be one of the reasons preventing the commercialization of this process. The properties of amorphous materials, which have long-range amorphous structure but short-range ordered structure, have attracted a lot of attention due to their superior chemical properties. Among them, the Ni-based amorphous alloys have been thoroughly studied as catalysts [8–13]. These have mainly been applied in the hydrogenation of various organic compounds and exhibit superior catalytic properties to the conventional hydrogenation catalysts, such as Raney Ni, Ni/SiO2, or Pd/C. If supported, amorphous alloys would be much more promising as catalysts due to the remarkable increases in the active surface area and in the thermal stability. We recently reported that the amorphous Ni–B(La)/Al2O3 can also be used to catalyze the formation of hydrogen peroxide from CO, H2O and O2 [14]. But the activity is low and the stability is not good either. In this paper, we report that NiP(B)/Al2O3 catalysts, prepared by a coating method, exhibit very good activity and stability. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalyst preparation Forty grams of γ-Al2O3 was first incipiently impregnated with an aqueous solution containing 11.35g of NiCl2. After drying at 120°C for 12h, the Ni2+ on the support was reduced by dropwise addition of an KBH4 solution in ethanol/water (BH4 −: Ni2+ =3:1; V ethanol/V water =1:1) at 0°C. The precipitated black substance was washed, firstly with deionized water until the pH became 7, and then three times with 99.5% ethanol. It was dried in nitrogen at 60°C and 101.3kPa for about 2h, and then kept in ethanol. Although Pd can be used to catalyze the deposition of NiP [15], activating the Al2O3 powder surface with amorphous NiB is simple and inexpensive. The above prepared NiB/Al2O3 was then transferred into a solution containing 0.1mol/l Ni(CH3COO)2 and 0.7mol/l NaH2PO2 for electroless plating at different temperatures, the total volume of the solution was 100ml. During the plating, the mixture was stirred vigorously. The prepared catalyst was washed, first with deionized water until the pH became 7, and then three times with ethanol and finally the material was kept in ethanol solution. At last the precursor was dried at 120°C for 10h in the air. Researchers have suggested that the amorphous NiP coating occurs according to the following equations [16]: H2PO2 − +2H2O=H2PO3 − +2H Ni2+ +2H=Ni+2H+ H2PO2 − +H=P+OH− +H2O H2PO2 − +H2O=H2PO3 − +2H2O Here Ni is the catalyst for these reactions. 2.2 Catalyst testing The reactions were carried out in a 500ml autoclave with 350ml distilled water containing about 0.015g of phosphoric acid and 4.6g of catalyst at 20°C, and the pH of the solution was 4. The partial pressures of CO and O2 were 500kPa and 1800kPa, respectively. The concentration of hydrogen peroxide formed was analyzed by the iodometric titration method. 2.3 Catalyst characterization The surface morphology and the particle size were measured by scanning electronic microscopy (SEM) performed on an XL 30 Philips electron microscope. The amorphous structures of the catalyst were determined by X-ray diffraction (XRD), and the in situ XRD was carried out on a D/maxII-2038 powder diffractometer using Cu Kα radiation. The surface composition and the electronic states of the elements in the catalyst were determined by X-ray photoelectron spectrometry (XPS, Perkin-Elmer, PHI-1600 ESCA System) using Mg Kα radiation (E b =1253.6eV). All binding energy (BE) values were referenced to the Al 2p peak at 74.1eV with an uncertainty of ±0.1eV. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Effects of plating temperature The catalysts used in this work are listed in Table 1 . Fig. 1 shows the time required at different plating temperatures, which is defined as the period from the feeding of NiB/Al2O3 into the solution to the end of the reaction, at which time no gas bubbles get out. It was found that the time required decreased markedly with the increase of the plating temperature from 20 to 40°C, which can be explained by the kinetics of the reaction: the plating reaction rate increased with the increase of temperature. However the time required decreased slowly with the further increase of the plating temperature, which might be due to the limited concentrations of the plating solution and NiB/A12O3. Fig. 2 shows the activities of the catalysts. Amorphous NiP(B)/Al2O3 catalysts prepared in 60°C (3#) and 80°C (2#) had better catalytic activities than those prepared at 40°C (4#) and 20°C (5#). One possible reason was that the coating reaction rate was slower in the lower temperature, which led to bigger Ni–P–B groups and little chance of exposed Ni. On the contrary, at the higher temperatures, smaller particles were formed due to the higher coating reaction rate, so more Ni atoms could be exposed and these could not be mantled by new Ni–P–B groups formed from self-catalyzed reactions later, which increased the active specific surface area and was advantageous to the catalytic reaction to prepare hydrogen peroxide. Therefore, with the same loading of Ni, the activity values of the catalysts prepared in different coating temperatures have large differences due to the amount of exposed active Ni atoms. 3.2 Effects of the initial pH values of plating The pH value is a key factor in the preparation of the catalysts. In the processes of the catalyst preparation the effects of the initial pH value of the plating solution on the catalysts activities were studied. The initial pH values of plating solution were adjusted with dilute sulfuric acid, and the pH value was in the range of 3.8–6.7. All catalysts had been treated as 3#. However, the pH value was not adjusted during the coating process because the coating rate was very fast and the processes were finished in a short time, according to Fig. 1. The activities of the catalysts prepared with different initial pH values are given in Fig. 3 . This showed that the catalysts prepared at the initial pH values of 5.1–5.4 had the highest catalytic activities. The pH value can determine the deposition rates of Ni and P, and then the contents of Ni and P on the surfaces of catalysts, as can be explained from the reaction equations. Increasing the pH value led to the decrease of the content of P. If the content of P is very low, there will be an aggregation of Ni in the catalyst, which is not beneficial to the dispersion of active Ni atoms. On the contrary, the higher content of P will bring on a small amount of exposed Ni, which will make the activity of the catalyst decrease. So the proper ratio of Ni to P must be controlled by adjusting the pH value of the plating solution, and 5.1–5.4 is the most suitable range of pH values. 3.3 Effects of the loadings of NiP(B) At 70°C, 13.5g of NiB/Al2O3 as precursor was put into the plating solutions, which all contained 0.1mol/l Ni(CH3COO)2 and 0.7mol/l NaH2PO2, but with different volumes. After plating, the precursors had the different loadings of NiP. All the catalysts were treated at 120°C for 10h in the air after coating. The relationship of the activities of the catalysts and the different loadings of NiP is shown in Fig. 4 . When the volume of the coating solution increased from 20 to 100ml, the catalytic activity increased gradually, but when the plating solution increased to 200ml, the activity decreased sharply. When the coating solution was in the range of 20–60ml, the prepared catalysts turned green after a 12h reaction, indicating that the catalysts had deactivated. Less plating solution made a small loading of NiP and only a small fraction of NiB on the surface was coated with NiP, letting some NiB remain uncovered with NiP. Since NiB is not stable in the reaction system, the catalyst deactivated quickly. But the catalysts coated by 80, 100 and 200ml plating solutions did not turn green, indicating that the catalysts were more stable than the catalysts coated by 20, 40 and 60ml plating solutions. Increasing the loading of NiP led to higher activity and more stability. But too much loadings of NiP (e.g. with 200ml plating solution) made the activity decrease, as is shown in Fig. 4. When too much NiP had deposited in the pores of the precursor, it choked the pores and led to the lost of surface. So the proper loadings (100ml coating solution) of amorphous NiP on the precursor would lead to good catalytic activities. 3.4 Effects of drying temperature Fig. 5 shows that drying temperatures of the catalysts had a remarkable effect on the NiP(B)/Al2O3 catalytic activities. The catalysts used in the experiments had been made in a plating solution containing 0.13mol/l Ni(CH3COO)2 and 0.7mol/l NaH2PO2 for electroless plating at 70°C, and the pH value was 5.1. Then the catalysts were treated at 90°C (6#), 120°C (7#), 150°C (8#), 180°C (9#), 250°C (10#), respectively, for 10h in the air. The activities of the catalysts had maximum values at 150°C. When the treating temperatures were higher than 150°C, the catalytic activities decreased because a part of the surface structure of the catalysts changed to the micro crystal, which was proved by the XRD characterization at higher temperature. The results revealed that the amorphous NiP(B) was the catalytic activity center. The effects of heat treatment can be explained as follows: first, while being heated, some B atoms in catalysts penetrated out to the outer layer from the inner layer and combined with NiP, forming the amorphous NiP(B); secondly, a part of P sublimated and more active centers appeared than on the fresh catalysts; thirdly, the drying process enhanced the mutual coalescence between the NiP(B) alloy and the support. So the proper drying temperature can raise catalytic activity and catalyst stability. 3.5 Comparison of NiP(B)/Al2O3 and NiB/Al2O3 Fig. 6 presents the stability tests over the catalysts 1# and 3#, in which the same amount of Ni was loaded (10wt.%). Evidently, catalyst 3# had a better activity than catalyst 1# and was very stable within the reaction time on line. However, catalyst 1# started to deactivate after 4h of reaction, which was much shorter than that of catalyst 3#. The results suggest that NiP(B)/Al2O3 is much better than NiB/Al2O3 for H2O2 synthesis from CO, H2O and oxygen. During the heat treatments, B was easily oxidized to form the oxide of B. Such an oxide does not have the supporting and protective effect on Ni, so Ni is also more easily oxidized owing to the big distance between Ni atoms in the NiB amorphous phase. The formed B2O3 and NiO also have an amorphous structure. But the mutual combination of NiP(B) formed by auto catalytic reaction makes the distance between Ni atoms in the active centers shorter than that between Ni and B formed by impregnation, and P and B atoms can simultaneously protect the Ni atom from oxidation by air. So NiP(B)/Al2O3 catalyst is much more stable and has a higher activity than NiB/Al2O3. 4 Catalyst characterization 4.1 Amorphous structure of catalyst Fig. 7 shows that the structure of the active components of the catalyst is amorphous. Catalysts 7#, 8# and 9# have the typical structure of Al2O3. The amorphous NiP(B) should have a flat peak at 44.5° (2θ) as fresh NiPB, but this peak is concealed by one of the peaks from Al2O3. Catalyst 10# has two weak peaks of micro crystal Ni2P, indicating that the amorphous NiP(B) was transformed to crystal phase at high temperatures. The interaction between Ni and P is much stronger than that between Ni and B in the amorphous NiP(B). During the heat treatment B in NiP(B) phase was oxidized and a fraction of P was lost from NiP(B) phase, so a small amounts of Ni2P crystallites was formed from NiP in NiP(B). Fig. 8 shows the structure of catalyst 11# after being heated at 420°C for about 10h. The amorphous NiP(B) transformed to crystallite Ni2P at first, and then to NiO whose typical peaks appeared in the XRD curve. The results showed that the drying temperatures remarkably changed the structures of the NiP(B)/Al2O3 catalysts, and gave some examples of the particular capability of amorphous NiP(B)/Al2O3 catalysts in the formation of hydrogen peroxide from carbon monoxide, water and oxygen. 4.2 SEM morphologies of amorphous NiP(B)/Al2O3 catalysts In Fig. 9 , pictures a–c show the different morphologies of NiP(B)/Al2O3 catalysts in different scales. Photo (c) shows a granule of a 20μm diameter particle in the catalyst. There are many small particles on the surface of the granule. Photo (b) shows that there are a lot of loose agglomerates of nano spherical particles which have a size of 20–150nm, and photo (a) clearly shows that the catalyst is cottonized; photo (d) and photo (g) show the surface morphology of the amorphous NiP(B)/Al2O3 which have been tested in the reaction for about 24h. Some colloidal substance covers the surface and the scale of surface grains become bigger compared with photo (b), which means the active grains had been changed during the reaction. This will be explained in the XPS analysis section. Photo (e) shows the surface morphology of fresh NiB/Al2O3. This is a good dispersed morphology with many small particles, and it is similar with photo (b), but the particles are also smaller than that in photo (b). Photo (f) shows the morphology of the deactivated NiB/Al2O3, and there is a big difference between (e) and (f). Photo (f) shows an irregular and sponge-like surface. Photo (k) shows that the fresh NiPB has regular nano grains and is very different with NiP(B)/Al2O3. NiP(B)/Al2O3 has a lot of irregular nano grains, which formed in different NiB spots on the surface of the support, but NiP(B)/Al2O3 has a bigger active surface and NiPB can congregate more easily than NiP(B)/Al2O3, so NiP(B)/Al2O3 is more suitable as a catalyst than NiPB. 4.3 XPS analysis of amorphous catalyst The standard binding energies of the involved substances are listed in Table 2 . In order to find the true reasons of catalysts deactivation, we have used two kinds of NiP(B)/Al2O3, pulverous catalyst and pellet catalyst, in the XPS analysis. The diameter of the support of the pellet catalyst was 1mm. The catalysts had been prepared with the same loading of NiCl2 and plated by the same volume of plating solution at the same conditions. Fig. 10 shows the XPS spectra of the pulverous NiP(B)/Al2O3 catalysts 3#, 3#R, 8# and 8#R. Fig. 11 shows the XPS spectra of NiP(B)/Al2O3 catalyst samples a–c. Sample a is the fresh NiP(B)/Al2O3 catalyst; sample b is the NiP(B)/Al2O3 catalyst which had been dried in the air at 120°C for 10h; sample c was the used catalyst from the sample b, which had catalyzed the synthesis of H2O2 for about 36h. In the P 2p spectrum, the peaks at 130 and 133.75eV are assigned to elemental phosphorus and oxidized phosphorus; the B 1s spectrum includes peaks of 187.8 and 193.3eV, which are ascribed to elemental B and oxidized B (B2O3); the Ni 2p3/2 spectrum includes elemental Ni (853eV) and oxidized Ni (856.75eV). So the XPS results reveal the presence of elemental P, B and Ni, which can form the amorphous NiP(B) alloy. The data also prove that the catalysts prepared by chemical coating method have a good ability of antioxidation and stability and that the existential P and B will contribute to keeping the valence state of elemental Ni stable. During NiP coating, a lot of byproduct, NiHPO3, had been produced in the plating solution, which had a small solubility in water (0.29g/100g H2O). The P 2p level in 133.75eV is close to the BaHPO3 (133.9eV) [17], so it can be concluded that the oxidized phosphorus in the catalyst surface layer is positively charged. The binding energy of NiO is 853.8eV, and Ni can only be oxidized to Ni2O3 when the temperature exceeds 400°C, so Ni does not combine with oxygen; however, the reported Ni 2p3/2 of NiSiO3 is 856.9eV. Thus, we can confirm that some NiHPO3 deposited on the surface of NiP(B)/Al2O3, and it will form some colloidal substance during the reaction. After 36h reaction, the peaks of elemental P, B and Ni in the used catalysts (3#R and 8#R) disappeared, so the NiP(B) alloy no longer existed on the surface of catalyst; at the same time, a lot of suspended particles had been found in the reaction solution, and the suspended particles can decompose the synthesized hydrogen peroxide, so the holistic catalytic activity dropped. But the NiP(B) alloy of the pellet catalyst remained good during the reaction, so the reaction solution was clean and had no suspended particles. Although their initial catalytic activities were smaller than that of the pulverous catalysts, they were stabler. This result has been shown in Fig. 12 . The XPS spectra of pellet catalysts a, b showed that the peaks of elemental P and Ni decreased and those of the oxidized Ni and P increased, which was owing to the sublimation of elemental P on the catalyst surface; accordingly, the proportion of NiHPO3 scaled up. So the heat treatment of catalysts can adjust the proportions of Ni and P. In the XPS spectrum of pellet catalyst c there is a strong peak of 191eV due to the overlap of the P 2S and B 1S orbits; this overlap has been shown in Fig. 13 . 5 Conclusions The supported amorphous catalysts NiP(B)/Al2O3 were prepared in two chemical reduction steps in water or water and ethanol solution. The plating temperature, the initial pH value of plating solution, the loading of NiP and the drying temperature significantly affected the catalysts activities. The different preparation conditions distinctly changed the number of the active sites. The NiP(B)/Al2O3 catalyst had been investigated by SEM, XRD and XPS. XRD showed that the structures of active components were amorphous; XPS results proved the existence of amorphous NiP(B) alloy on the surface of the catalyst, which was the active component for the synthesis of H2O2; SEM results showed that the active components were well dispersed on the support. The main reason of catalysts deactivation was analyzed by SEM and XPS characterization; it was because the active components broke off from the support. The highest production rate of H2O2 synthesis from CO/O2 and H2O reported in the literature is 0.1mmol/(gh) over 5% Pd/CaCO3 and 1% Ru/graphite catalysts. The maximal rate on Ni–La–B/Al2O3 is ca. 0.07mmol/(gh). The present production rate over NiP(B)/Al2O3 catalyst reaches 0.228mmol/(gh). So the NiP(B)/Al2O3 catalyst has better activity than Ni–La–B/Al2O3 and the noble catalyst. Further developments of supported Ni catalyst would be valuable to develop a catalyst for H2O2 synthesis from CO, water and oxygen. coredata.dc:description: Amorphous NiP(B)/Al2O3 catalysts were prepared by a coating method. The factors that influence the preparation of the catalysts, such as plating temperature, the initial pH value of the plating solution, the loadings of NiP and the temperature of heat treatment, were studied in detail. The catalysts were characterized with XRD, SEM and XPS, and were studied in the reaction for the synthesis of hydrogen peroxide from carbon monoxide, water and oxygen. The results showed that the catalysts had amorphous structure with Ni–P–B alloy formed on the surface; that the catalysts had better activity and stability than the catalysts reported previously when the H2O2 production rate reached 0.228mmol/(gh), which is higher than the maximum rate of 0.1mmol/(gh) over noble catalysts (5% Pd/CaCO3 and 1% Ru/graphite) and 0.07mmol/(gh) over Ni–La–B/Al2O3 catalyst; and that the preparation conditions significantly influenced the activities of the catalysts. The higher stability values of the catalysts were attributed to the amorphous Ni–P–B structure.
coredata.dc:title: Synthesis of hydrogen peroxide from carbon monoxide, water and oxygen catalyzed by amorphous NiP(B)/Al2O3
